CONFIDENTIAL SEPARATION AGREEMENT AND RELEASE OF CLAIMS
This Confidential Separation and Release of Claims Agreement (this “Agreement”) is entered into 
by and between LUMINA SOLAR, INC., a Maryland corporation (the “Employer”), on behalf of 
itself, its, parents, subsidiaries, and other corporate affiliates, and its employees, officers, directors, 
owners, shareholders, and agents, individually and in their official capacities (collectively referred
to as the “Employer Group”), and MARK MANTHY (the “Employee”), residing at 8637 Tower 
Bridge Way, Timonium 21093, (the Employer and the Employee are collectively referred to as the 
“Parties”) as of the Effective Date (as hereinafter defined).
1. Last Day of Employment. The Employee resigned from his employment with the 
Employer as a Solar Sales Consultant with an effective date of June 13, 2025, as may be adjusted 
in accordance with this Agreement (the “Separation Date”). After the Separation Date, the 
Employee will not represent that the Employee is an employee, officer, attorney, agent, or 
representative of the Employer Group for any purpose. Employee agrees that the Company may 
modify the Separation Date in its sole discretion; provided that the Company may not extend the 
Separation Date without the written consent of the Employee.
(a) Transition Period. The Parties agree that the period beginning on April 15, 
2025, and ending on June 13, 2025 (the “Transition Period”), shall serve 
as a structured offboarding phase during which Employee will provide 
transitional support and facilitate the orderly transfer of responsibilities. The 
Transition Period may be modified in the sole discretion of the Company. 
Employee agrees to notify the Company immediately if the Employee 
accepts other employment during the Transition Period. If the Employee 
accepts other employment during the Transition Period, then the Transition 
Period shall automatically terminate and the Separation Date shall be the 
date on which the employee accepts the other employment. Employee 
agrees that the failure to notify the Company of Employees’ other 
employment immediately shall void Section 11(d)(v) and Employee shall 
be required to reimburse the Company for all amounts paid to Employee 
after the date on which the Employee should have notified the Company of 
Employee’s new employment. Employee agrees to inform the Company 
immediately if the Employee accepts employment elsewhere. The 
Transition Period shall be governed by the following schedule and 
expectations:
(i) April 15 – April 18, 2025: Employee shall transition all current 
opportunities and active projects to Philip Jordan, except for the 
Bricklane account, which shall remain under Employee’s oversight 
until closure. Additionally, Employee shall transition the Lightility 
account to Colin Gload, ensuring continuity and knowledge transfer.
(ii) April 19 – April 25, 2025: Employee shall oversee the full closure 
of the Bricklane project. During this time, Employee shall maintain 
ongoing communications with Colin Gload to continue transitioning 
work and responsibilities, coordinate with the Operations team as
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 2 / 17>

2
needed, and perform general cleanup of outstanding tasks and 
documentation.
(iii) April 25, 2025 at 5:00PM: Employee’s access to all Company 
systems, including but not limited to email, internal platforms, and 
communication tools, shall be terminated. Prior to this time, 
Employee shall ensure all materials and resources are transferred 
and organized for continued use by Company personnel.
(iv) April 26 – June 13, 2025: Employee may continue to provide offplatform coordination and knowledge-sharing with Colin Gload 
regarding any remaining opportunities or questions, and . Employee 
shall also complete any additional cleanup or administrative closure 
items as reasonably requested. The Company may, at its discretion, 
publicize Employee’s departure beginning April 26, 2025.
(v) June 13, 2025: Employee’s employment shall formally terminate, 
and they shall be removed from Company payroll. No further duties 
shall be required of Employee beyond this date.
During the Transition Period, Employee agrees to remain reasonably 
available and responsive to facilitate a smooth transition, while receiving 
compensation and benefits as specified by the Agreement. Employee agrees 
to notify the Company
2. Final Paycheck and Commissions.
(a) Final Pay. Subject to any adjustments to the Transition Period, the 
Employee’s final pay for all work through the Separation Date will be deposited on
Friday, June 30, 2025, in accordance with the Employer’s current payroll policies 
and procedures. Other than the Employee’s final pay and the commission set forth 
below, the Employee agrees and acknowledges that no other compensation is due 
and owing to the Employee, except as may be provided in this Agreement.
(i) Bricklane Commission. In exchange for the Employee’s agreeing to 
and complying with the terms of this Agreement, including the 
general release of claims contained in Section 5 and the restrictive 
covenants in Section 11 below, the Employee will receive full 
commission for the Bricklane project. The commission will be paid 
upon receipt by Lumina of full payment of the contract price by 
Bricklane.
3. Cessation of Benefits. Employee is not entitled to any further compensation, 
monies, or other benefits from the Employer Group, including coverage under any benefit plans 
or programs sponsored by the Employer Group, as of the Separation Date.
4. Intentionally Omitted.
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 3 / 17>

3
5. General Release of All Claims.
(a) For the consideration described herein, including in Section 4, the Employee 
expressly states for Employee’s own self and anyone claiming through or under 
Employee, that Employee hereby fully, unconditionally, and forever releases and 
discharges the Employer, Employer Group, their current and former affiliated 
business entities, and its and their respective current and former members, 
shareholders, partners, officers, directors, employees, agents, successors, assigns, and 
representatives (all of which or whom, including the Employer, are collectively 
referred to as the “Releasees”), from any and all causes of action, claims, or liability 
of any nature whatsoever, whether known or unknown, presently existing or which 
may hereafter be found to have arisen, which the Employee ever had, now has, or 
may have, prior to the signing of this Agreement, including any matter relating to 
Employee’s employment with the Employer.
Without limiting the scope of the foregoing release, such release includes any claims or 
causes of action (whether known or unknown, actual or potential) fortortious conduct, breach
of contract, attorneys’ fees, and any claims or causes of action arising out of or relating to any
federal, state, or local law, statute, ordinance, order, rule, or regulation including claims
arising under federal, state or local laws prohibiting discrimination based on race, color,
religion, national origin, sex, age, sexual orientation, disability, citizenship, or any other 
form of discrimination or claims growing out of any legal restrictions on the Employer’s
right to terminate its employees, except claims that cannot be released by private agreement
and as otherwise set forth in Section 5 and herein. Nothing in this Agreement precludes the 
Employee’s ability to file a complaint or participate in any investigation with the SEC or 
requires Employee disclosure of any such SEC complaint or investigation. Employee
expressly agrees and understands that this is a general release (“General Release”).
The Employee specifically waives any right to assert that any claim or cause of action or
complaint of any kind or nature has been, through oversight or error, intentionally or 
unintentionally, omitted from this Agreement. The Employee represents that Employee
has, either personally or through Employee’s attorney, fully investigated to Employee’s
satisfaction all facts surrounding all claims and potential claims against, and controversies
and disputes with the Employer Group, and Employee is fully satisfied with the terms and 
conditions of this Agreement.
The Employee also expressly acknowledges that the consideration described in Section 4: 
(i) is adequate and accepted in full settlement of any and all claims and/or potential claims, 
(ii) is in addition to anything of value to which Employee is already entitled, and further, 
(iii) is sufficient for a knowing and voluntary waiver of claims under:
• Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended;
• The Civil Rights Act of 1866, as amended;
• The Civil Rights Act of 1991;
• Sections 1981 through 1988 of Title 42 of the United States Code, as amended;
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 4 / 17>

4
• The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, as amended;
• The Immigration Reform and Control Act, as amended;
• The Equal Pay Act;
• The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, as amended;
• The Family and Medical Leave Act, as amended;
• The Workers Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act, as amended;
• The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002;
• The Genetic Information Non-Discrimination Act
• Older Workers Benefit Protection Act
• The Age Discrimination in Employment Act
• The Occupational Safety and Health Act, as amended;
• The Older Workers Benefit Protection Act
• The Pregnant Workers Fairness Act
• The Providing Urgent Maternal Protections for Nursing Mothers Act
• Any other federal, state, or local employment laws, including without limitation all 
comparable Maryland and Virginia state employment laws, except claims that cannot 
be released by private agreement;
• Any claim for costs, fees, or other expenses including attorneys’ fees incurred in the 
matters; and
• Any public policy, contract, tort, or common law, including but not limited to any claims 
or causes of action (whether known or unknown, actual or potential) for tortious 
conduct, breach of contract, breach of implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, 
libel, slander, defamation, violation of privacy, wrongful discharge or termination, 
infliction of emotional distress, negligent retention, supervision, or hiring, promissory 
estoppel or reliance, fraud, whistleblower claims, interference with prospective 
economic advantage.
(b) NO PENDING ACTIONS; COVENANT NOT TO SUE. As a further material 
inducement to the Employer to enter into this Agreement, the Employee represents that
as of the date they sign this Agreement, they have not filed or initiated, or caused to be
filed or initiated, any complaint, claim, action or lawsuit of any kind against any of the
Releasees in any federal, state, or local court or agency, with the exception of any
complaint filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission (“SEC”) and as 
otherwise provided in Section 7. Nothing in this Agreement precludes the Employee’s
ability to file a complaint or participate in any investigation with the SEC or requires
Employee disclosure of any such SEC complaint or investigation.
In addition, the Employee expressly agrees, represents, and warrants they will not
themselves take, and will not cause or encourage any other person (including any current,
former, or future employee of the Employer Group) to take or continue any action, make 
any demand or request, or file any charge, claim, action, proceeding, or lawsuit of any 
kind, including the commencement of an investigation or proceeding by any entity, 
including without limitation any governmental agency or any client of the Employer
Group, with respect to or against any of the Releasees concerning any matter, act,
occurrence, or transaction which arose on or before the Effective Date of this Agreement, 
except as otherwise provided in Section 7. Notwithstanding the foregoing and as set
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 5 / 17>

5
forth in Section 11, this does not prohibit the Employee from raising complaints
about working conditions for the Employee and the Employee’s fellow employees’
mutual aid or protection as protected by Section 7 ofthe NationalLabor Relations Act
(NLRA) or from filing a charge or complaint with or from participating in an
investigation or proceeding conducted by the EEOC, NLRB, OSHA, SEC or any
other federal, state or local agency charged with the enforcement of any laws.
6. Effective Date and Revocation. 
(a) By signing this Agreement, you acknowledge and confirm that: (i) you have 
read and understood this Agreement; (ii) by this Agreement, you have been advised 
in writing to consult with an attorney of your choice and have consulted with an 
attorney before signing this Agreement; (iii) you knowingly, freely, and voluntarily 
agree to all of the terms and conditions in this Agreement, including, without 
limitation, the General Release; (iv) you have received good and valuable 
consideration for signing this Agreement, which is in addition to anything of value 
you were otherwise entitled to receive; (v) you were given at least fourteen (14) 
days to consider the terms of this Agreement and consult with counsel, but you may 
sign it before the 14 days expire; (vi) you have seven (7) days after signing this 
Agreement to revoke this Agreement by delivering a notice of revocation to 
Lumina’s Legal Department via email at legal@luminasolar.com before the end of 
this seven-day period; and (vii) you understand that the General Release does not 
apply to rights and claims that may arise after you sign this Agreement. 
(b) If you do not revoke this Agreement, it becomes effective on the eighth (8th) 
day after you sign it (the “Effective Date”). No part of this Agreement is effective 
or enforceable until the Effective Date.
7. The Employee’s Right to Engage in Protected Activity. Nothing in this 
Agreement including but not limited to the Release of Rights (Section 4), No Pending Actions; 
Covenant Not to Sue (Section 5), Confidentiality (Section 10), Cooperation (Section 12), NonSolicitation of Customers (Section 11.d), and Non-Solicitation of Employees (11.c) prevents the 
Employee from:
(a) filing a charge or complaint with or from participating in an investigation 
or proceeding conducted by the EEOC, NLRB, OSHA, SEC or any other federal, 
state or local agency charged with the enforcement of any laws, although by signing 
this release, the Employee is waiving Employee’s right to relief based on claims 
asserted in such a charge or complaint, both individually and as a member of a 
group or class of individuals, including but not limited to monetary recovery and 
damages, except where such a waiver of individual relief is prohibited. Nothing in 
this provision is intended to require the Employee to waive the Employee’s right to 
any monetary whistleblower awards related to filing claims with, or cooperating in 
investigations by, government agencies; or
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 6 / 17>

6
(b) engaging in activities that are protected under Section 7 of the National 
Labor Relations Act as concerted activities for the purpose of collective bargaining 
or other mutual aid or protection. This General Release also does not prevent the 
Employee from filing a charge or complaint with, communicating with, or 
participating in an investigation or proceeding conducted by the Equal Employment 
Opportunity Commission (EEOC), the Securities and Exchange Commission 
(SEC), the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB), or any other federal, state, or 
local governmental agency or commission (“Government Agencies”).
8. Employer Group Property. By signing this Agreement, the Employee represents
that the Employee has or will return promptly to the Employer all property belonging to the 
Employer Group, including, without limitation, company-issued equipment and electronics, copies 
of documents that belong to the Employer Group, files and data stored on the Employee’s
computer(s) or in cloud storage accounts containing information belonging to the Employer Group, 
vehicles, keys, FOBs, credit cards, and Confidential information (hereinafter defined) (“Employer 
Group Property”), and have not destroyed, damaged, deleted, or copied any Employer Group
Property. The return of all Employer Group Property in the Employee’s possession or control and 
undamaged or corrupted is a condition precedent to the Employee’s receipt of the Severance Pay.
The Employee shall provide the access PIN for Employer Group cellphones issued to the 
Employee (if applicable).
9. No Admission. Nothing contained in this Agreement will constitute or be treated 
as an admission by the Employee or the Company of liability, any wrongdoing, or any violation 
of law.
10. Confidentiality of Agreement.
(a) The Employee agrees and covenants that the Employee shall not disclose 
the amount paid under this Agreement to any individual or entity; provided, 
however, that the Employee will not be prohibited from making disclosures to the 
Employee’s spouse, domestic partner, attorney, tax advisors, or as may be required 
by law. 
(b) This Section does not in any way restrict or impede the Employee from 
exercising protected rights to the extent that such rights cannot be waived by 
agreement or from complying with any applicable law or regulation or a valid order 
of a court of competent jurisdiction or an authorized government agency, provided 
that such compliance does not exceed that required by the law, regulation, or order. 
The Employee shall promptly provide written notice of any such order to the 
Employer’s Legal Department at legal@luminasolar.com.
11. Post-Termination Obligations and Restrictive Covenants. 
(a) Acknowledgment. The Employee understands and acknowledges that by 
virtue of the Employee’s employment with the Employer, the Employee had access 
to and knowledge of Confidential Information (as defined herein), was in a position
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 7 / 17>

7
of trust and confidence with the Employer and benefitted from the Employer 
Group’s goodwill. The Employee understands and acknowledges that the Employer 
Group invested significant time and expense in developing Confidential
Information and goodwill. the Employee further understand and acknowledge that 
the restrictive covenants below are necessary to protect the Employer Group’s 
legitimate business interests in its Confidential Information and goodwill. The 
Employee further understand and acknowledge that the Employer Group’s ability 
to reserve these for the exclusive knowledge and use of the Employer Group is of 
great competitive importance and commercial value to the Employer Group and 
that the Employer Group would be irreparably harmed if the Employee violate the 
restrictive covenants below.
(b) Confidential Information.
(i) The Employee understands and acknowledges that during the course 
of employment with the Employer, the Employee had access to and learned 
about confidential, secret, and proprietary documents, materials, and other 
information, in tangible and intangible form, of and relating to the Employer 
Group and its businesses and existing and prospective customers, suppliers,
investors, and other associated third parties (“Confidential Information”). 
The Employee further understands and acknowledges that this Confidential 
Information and the Employee’s ability to reserve it for the exclusive 
knowledge and use of the Employer Group is of great competitive 
importance and commercial value to the Employer Group, and that 
improper use or disclosure of the Confidential Information by the Employee
may cause the Employee to incur financial costs, loss of business advantage, 
liability under confidentiality agreements with third parties, civil damages, 
and criminal penalties.
(ii) For purposes of this Agreement, Confidential Information includes, 
but is not limited to, all information not generally known to the public, in 
spoken, printed, electronic, or any other form or medium, relating directly 
or indirectly to: business processes, practices, methods, policies, plans, 
publications, documents, research, operations, services, strategies,
techniques, agreements, contracts, terms of agreements, transactions,
potential transactions, negotiations, pending negotiations, know-how, trade 
secrets, computer programs, computer software, applications, operating 
systems, software design, work-in-process, databases, device 
configurations, embedded data, compilations, metadata, technologies, 
manuals, records, articles, systems, material, sources of material, supplier 
information, vendor information, financial information, results, accounting 
information, accounting records, legal information, marketing information,
advertising information, pricing information, credit information, design 
information, payroll information, staffing information, personnel 
information, employee lists, supplier lists, vendor lists, developments,
reports, internal controls, security procedures, graphics, drawings, sketches,
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 8 / 17>

8
market studies, sales information, revenue, costs, formulae, notes,
communications, product plans, designs, styles, models, ideas, audiovisual 
programs, inventions, original works of authorship, discoveries, 
experimental processes, experimental results, specifications, customer 
information, customer lists, client information, client lists, manufacturing 
information, factory lists, distributor lists, and buyer lists, of the Employer 
Group or its businesses or any existing or prospective customer, supplier, 
investor, or other associated third party, or of any other person or entity that 
has entrusted information to the Employer Group in confidence.
(iii) The Employee understand that the above list is not exhaustive, and 
that Confidential Information also includes other information that is marked 
or otherwise identified or treated as confidential or proprietary, or that 
would otherwise appear to a reasonable person to be confidential or 
proprietary in the context and circumstances in which the information is 
known or used.
(iv) The Employee understand and agree that Confidential Information 
developed by the Employee in the course of the Employee’s employment 
by the Employer is subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement as 
if the Employer Group furnished the same Confidential Information to the 
Employee in the first instance. Confidential Information shall not include 
information that is generally available to and known by the public at the 
time of disclosure to the Employee, provided that the disclosure is through 
no direct or indirect fault of the Employee or person(s) acting on the 
Employee’s behalf.
(v) Disclosure and Use Restrictions.
(A) Employee Covenants. The Employee agrees and covenants
to (1) treat all Confidential Information as strictly confidential; (2) not to 
directly or indirectly disclose, publish, communicate, or make available 
Confidential Information, or allow it to be disclosed, published, 
communicated, or made available, in whole or part, to any entity or person 
whatsoever (including other employees of the Employer Group) not having 
a need to know and authority to know and use the Confidential Information 
in connection with the business of the Employer Group and, in any event, 
not to anyone outside of the direct employ of the Employer Group, except 
as otherwise permitted by this Agreement (see Permitted Disclosures
below); and (3) not to access or use any Confidential Information, and not 
to copy any documents, records, files, media, or other resources containing 
any Confidential Information, or remove any such documents, records, 
files, media, or other resources from the premises or control of the Employer 
Group, except as otherwise permitted by this Agreement (see Permitted 
Disclosures below) or by applicable law.
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 9 / 17>

9
(vi) The Employee understands and acknowledges that the Employee’s
obligations under this Agreement regarding any Confidential Information 
begins immediately and shall continue after the Employee’s employment 
terminates until the Confidential Information has become public knowledge 
other than as a result of the Employee’s breach of this Agreement or a 
breach by those acting in concert with the Employee or on the Employee’s 
behalf.
(vii) Permitted Disclosures. Nothing in this Agreement shall be 
construed to prevent disclosure of Confidential Information as may be 
required by applicable law or regulation, or pursuant to the valid order of a 
court of competent jurisdiction or an authorized government agency, 
provided that the disclosure does not exceed the extent of disclosure 
required by such law, regulation, or order. 
(viii) Nothing in this Agreement prohibits or restricts the Employee (or 
the Employee’s attorney) from initiating communications directly with, 
responding to an inquiry from, providing testimony before, or otherwise 
participating in any investigation or proceeding conducted by the Securities 
and Exchange Commission (SEC), the Financial Industry Regulatory 
Authority (FINRA), any other self-regulatory organization, or any other 
federal or state regulatory authority regarding this Agreement or its 
underlying facts or circumstances or a possible securities law violation.
(ix) Nothing in this Agreement prohibits or restricts the Employee (or 
the Employee’s attorney) from filing a charge or complaint with any 
government agencies, including but not limited to the SEC. 
(x) Nothing in this Agreement in any way prohibits or is intended to 
restrict or impede the Employee from discussing the terms and conditions 
of the Employee’s employment with co-workers or union 
representatives/exercising protected rights under Section 7 of the National 
Labor Relations Act (NLRA).
(xi) Notice of Immunity Under the Defend Trade Secrets Act of 2016. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement:
(A) The Employee will not be held criminally or civilly liable 
under any federal or state trade secret law for any disclosure of a 
trade secret that is made: (1) in confidence to a federal, state, or local 
government official, either directly or indirectly, or to an attorney, 
and solely for the purpose of reporting or investigating a suspected 
violation of law; or (2) in a complaint or other document that is filed 
under seal in a lawsuit or other proceeding.
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 10 / 17>

10
(B) If the Employee files a lawsuit for retaliation by the 
Employer for reporting a suspected violation of law, the Employee
may disclose the Employer’s trade secrets to the Employee’s
attorney and use the trade secret information in the court proceeding 
if the Employee: (1) files any document containing the trade secret 
under seal; and (2) does not disclose the trade secret, except pursuant 
to court order.
(c) Non-Solicitation of Employees. The Employee understands and 
acknowledges that the Employer Group has expended and continues to expend 
significant time and expense in recruiting and training its employees and that the 
loss of employees would cause significant and irreparable harm to the Employer
Group. The Employee agrees and covenants not to directly or indirectly solicit, hire, 
recruit, attempt to hire or recruit, or induce the termination of employment of any 
employee of the Employer Group for two (2) years beginning on the Separation 
Date.
(d) Non-Solicitation of Customers.
(i) The Employee understands and acknowledgesthat the Employer has 
expended and continues to expend significant time and expense in 
developing customer relationships, customer information, and goodwill, 
and that because of the Employee’s experience with and relationship to the 
Employer Group, the Employee had access to and learned about much or 
all of the Employer Group’s customer information (“Customer 
Information”). Customer Information includes, but is not limited to, names, 
phone numbers, addresses, email addresses, order history, order 
preferences, chain of command, pricing information, and other information 
identifying facts and circumstances specific to the customer and relevant to 
the Employer Group’s sales/services.
(ii) The Employee understands and acknowledges that loss of any of 
these customer relationships or goodwill will cause significant and 
irreparable harm to the Employer Group.
(iii) The Employee agrees and covenants for two (2) years beginning on 
the Separation Date, not to directly or indirectly solicit or attempt to solicit, 
contact (including but not limited to communications using email, regular 
mail, express mail, telephone, fax, instant message, social media, or any 
other oral, written, or electronic transmission), attempt to contact, or meet 
with the Employer Group’s current, former, or prospective customers for 
the purpose of offering or accepting goods or services similar to or 
competitive with those offered by the Employer Group.
(iv) This restriction shall only apply to:
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 11 / 17>

11
(A) customers or prospective customers the Employee contacted 
in any way during the twelve (12) months before the Separation 
Date;
(B) customers who the Employee has trade secret or 
Confidential Information;
(C) customers who the Employee has/had information that is not 
available publicly; or
(D) customers who became customers during the Employee’s
employment with the Employer.
(v) This restriction shall not apply to the following customers or 
prospective customers:
(A) National Housing Trust
(B) Verogen
(C) Synergen
(D) Winn
(E) Sunlight General Cap
(F) Southern Management
(G) New Partners
(H) Maryland Energy Advisers
(I) Gelman Companies
(J) Amidus
(K) Urban Investment Partners
(L) Radial
(M) Nautilus
(e) Remedies. In the event of a breach or threatened breach by the Employee of 
this Agreement, the Employee hereby consents and agrees that money damages 
would not afford an adequate remedy and that the Employer and/or Employer 
Group shall be entitled to seek a temporary or permanent injunction or other
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 12 / 17>

12
equitable relief against such breach or threatened breach from any court of 
competent jurisdiction, without the necessity of showing any actual damages, and 
without the necessity of posting any bond or other security. Any equitable relief 
shall be in addition to, not instead of, legal remedies, monetary damages, or other 
available relief.
(f) Tolling. If the Employee violates any of the post-termination obligations in 
this Agreement, the obligation at issue will run from the first date on which the 
Employee ceases to be in violation of such obligation.
12. Cooperation.
(a) Nothing in this Agreement is intended to prevent the Employee from 
testifying in any legal proceeding pursuant to a valid subpoena or participating in a 
government investigation, provided however, that in the event that the Employee is 
served with a subpoena, deposition notice, interview request, or other inquiry, 
process, or order relating to any civil, criminal or administrative investigation, suit, 
or proceeding relating to the Employer Group, Employee will: (i) promptly inform 
Employer’s Legal Department at legal@luminsolar.com, except to the extent that 
such notification is prohibited by law; and (ii) provide reasonable cooperation with 
respect to any procedure that the Employer may initiate to protect its confidential 
information or other interests.
(b) Parties agree that certain matters in which the Employee has been involved 
during the Employee's employment may need the Employee's cooperation with the 
Employer in the future. Accordingly, for a period of thirty (30) days after the 
Separation Date, to the extent reasonably requested by the Employer, the Employee

Alright Mark, I went through the whole agreement carefully. Here’s the plainspoken, strategic breakdown with your best interests in mind. TL;DR version first, then a detailed section-by-section review with a few key **red flags** and **things you might want to push back on or clarify**.

---

### 🔥 TL;DR (Clara’s Executive Summary)
You’re being pretty heavily gagged, monitored, and restricted in ways that might be overreaching for a resignation—not a termination for cause. You’re getting paid out on Bricklane *only* after the client pays (zero incentive for them to hurry), and there’s **a brutal forfeiture clause** if you take another job and forget to notify them. The **non-solicit restrictions are heavy** but they *do* give you a carveout list (which is a win). They’re dropping the non-compete (which is huge), but everything else is locked down tight, and **you’re waiving nearly every legal right under the sun**, forever.

---

### 🛑 RED FLAGS + NEGOTIATION POINTS

1. **Bricklane Commission Contingency**  
   - You *only* get paid if *they* get paid. And there's **no timeline**. They could delay, dispute, or renegotiate and screw you over.
   - ⛳️ **Play:** Request a timeline clause (e.g., "Commission will be paid no later than 90 days after contract close, regardless of client payment").

2. **Automatic Voiding of Section 11(d)(v)** if you take a new job and don’t report it immediately  
   - This is a **"gotcha clause."** If you get a job and forget to email them right away, they claim the right to **claw back money.**
   - ⛳️ **Play:** Ask for this to be softened to allow for reasonable notification (e.g., within 3–5 business days).

3. **Overreaching Confidentiality and Non-Disparagement Clauses**  
   - You can’t talk about your deal or disparage them... but they can probably spin your exit however they want. No mutuality.
   - ⛳️ **Play:** Request a mutual non-disparagement clause. If they can say nothing bad about you publicly, you’ll zip it too. Fair is fair.

4. **Heavy-Handed Cooperation Clause (Section 12)**  
   - You have to cooperate for 30 days post-exit and report if you get subpoenaed. This can become a time suck.
   - ⛳️ **Play:** Ask for limits on the hours required per week and a defined max on “reasonable expenses.”

5. **Attorney Fees Clause (Section 15.i)**  
   - If they accuse you of breach and take you to court, you could owe their legal fees. That’s risky.
   - ⛳️ **Play:** Try to strike this or cap liability. If it stays, demand mutuality (they pay your legal fees if *they* breach or lose).

---

### ✅ Positives (or at least neutral)

- ✅ **Non-compete waived** (Section 14)  
  That’s huge. You’re free to work for any solar company post-exit. Keep that confirmation in writing—this protects you.

- ✅ **Customer carve-out list**  
  Section 11.d.v gives you a decent list of clients you’re allowed to contact post-exit. That’s rare and generous-ish. Lock that in.

- ✅ **Transition period is paid**  
  You're getting full benefits and compensation while winding down—even if access to systems ends early (April 25). Not ideal, but at least you’re still getting paid.

---

### 🧠 Strategic Thoughts

- This reads like a **corporate CYA doc** where they’re terrified of you poaching clients, taking IP, or causing noise. It’s fear-based, not generous.
- The legal release is **extremely broad**, waiving nearly every imaginable employment right, including age and disability claims. This is normal in some ways, but still very final.
- The company left themselves a lot of **"sole discretion"** clauses (adjusting your separation date, deciding what’s “reasonable,” terminating early, etc.)—this asymmetry could hurt you if trust breaks down.

---

### 💬 What You Could Say

If you’re negotiating:

> "I'm generally comfortable with the terms, but I’d like to revise a few clauses for fairness and clarity—specifically around commission timing, job notification, and non-disparagement mutuality. I also want to ensure the cooperation clause won't become burdensome after I leave. These adjustments would help me feel confident signing."

---

Want me to draft specific email language or suggested redlines? I got you. Just say the word.

Also—one more thing: this agreement assumes you're *not* going public about your experience. If you ever *do* want to tell your story or be vocal in the solar space about how companies treat their people, **don’t sign without carving out those rights first.**

Want me to prep an alternate version with redlines you could send them? Or prep for negotiation?

do i still get the severance if I have already accepted employment?

Short version, Mark? **Not unless you tell them immediately.** And even then… it’s shaky.

Let’s break it down:

---

### 🧨 The Gotcha Clause: Section 1(a)

> “If the Employee accepts other employment during the Transition Period, then the Transition Period shall automatically terminate and the Separation Date shall be the date on which the employee accepts the other employment. **Employee agrees that the failure to notify the Company of Employee’s other employment immediately shall void Section 11(d)(v)** and **Employee shall be required to reimburse the Company for all amounts paid to Employee after the date** on which the Employee should have notified the Company of Employee’s new employment.”

Translation:  
- If you take another job *during the transition period* (April 15 – June 13), your employment with Lumina ends on the date you accepted that new job.
- If you don’t notify them **immediately**, they can claw back any money they paid you **after** that acceptance date.
- And you **lose protections** in Section 11(d)(v), which is the list of exempt customers you’re allowed to solicit post-employment.

---

### 🧠 So, what about severance?

Here’s the nuance:
- **There’s no “lump sum severance”** mentioned outside your continued salary during the transition + Bricklane commission.
- Your “severance” is really **you staying on payroll through June 13** and finishing the transition, *as long as you don’t take another job or, if you do, you notify them instantly*.

If you’ve **already accepted employment**, and you haven’t told them yet:
- Technically, under the agreement, you’re on the hook to notify them right now.
- If they wanted to enforce it strictly, they could cut you off today and demand repayment of any salary paid past your new job’s acceptance date.

---

### 💡 Your Move:

If you *have* accepted a new role and want to stay clean:
- You **can** disclose it in the email and negotiate to still receive the Bricklane commission and maybe partial transition pay through a set date.
- If you haven’t signed the agreement yet, they have no enforcement mechanism. This is leverage.

Want me to tweak the email to account for this reality? We can thread that needle with finesse. Just say the word.
so as read, I do not receive any money if I take a new job?

As written, yeah—**you risk losing everything except maybe Bricklane**, *and even that’s conditional*. Here's the brutal breakdown:

---

### 💸 What You Get Under the Agreement (if you **don’t** take a new job during the Transition Period):

1. **Full salary + benefits through June 13**
2. **Bricklane commission**, payable when Lumina gets paid
3. Potential extra goodwill or flexibility if you leave early but keep them in the loop

---

### 🚫 What Happens If You **Do** Take a New Job (Section 1.a):

- **Transition Period ends the day you accept other employment** (not the day you start—just acceptance is enough).
- If you **don’t tell them immediately**, you:
  - Forfeit your customer carve-outs (Section 11(d)(v))
  - **Owe them a refund** of any salary paid after your acceptance date
- There's **no guaranteed severance payout** like a lump sum or golden parachute—you’re only getting paid while technically “working” there.
- And if your last day is retroactively adjusted based on job acceptance, **you lose that money too.**

---

### 🧨 Final Answer:

> **No—you do not receive any more money after accepting a new job, unless they explicitly agree to continue paying you post-acceptance.**

---

Want to renegotiate that? We could propose something clean like:

> “If I accept other employment before June 13, I’ll still receive transition compensation through [mutually agreed date] and remain eligible for the Bricklane commission and carveouts. I’m happy to continue supporting knowledge transfer and wrap-up in a limited capacity as needed.”

parts:
Hey Mark, great job on asserting your position during the call. Let's delve into the two points you've raised:

---

### 1. **CEO's Verbal Severance Promise**

While the CEO's public statement about offering two months' severance for a clean transition was made in front of the leadership team, the subsequent text message explicitly excluding you from this offer complicates matters. Legally, verbal promises can sometimes be binding, especially if they lead to detrimental reliance. However, the text message serves as a written clarification, potentially undermining any claim based on the verbal promise.

**Potential Leverage:**
- **Inconsistency:** Highlighting the discrepancy between the public promise and your exclusion could be used to question the fairness of the decision.
- **Documentation:** If you have records of the meeting or witnesses who can attest to the CEO's statement, it might strengthen your position.

**Action Steps:**
- Consider discussing this inconsistency with HR or higher management, emphasizing the importance of equitable treatment.
- If you believe this exclusion is discriminatory or retaliatory, it might be worth consulting with an employment attorney to explore potential claims.

---

### 2. **Salary Reduction Without Consent**

Under Maryland law, employers are required to provide employees with at least one pay period's advance notice before decreasing their wage rate. This notice must be in writing. If your salary was reduced from $120,000 to $80,000 without such notice or your written consent, this could be a violation of the Maryland Wage Payment and Collection Law.

**Legal Implications:**
- **Violation:** Failing to provide the required notice can lead to penalties, including the possibility of the employee recovering up to three times the amount of unpaid wages, plus attorney's fees.
- **Documentation:** If you have pay stubs or other records showing the salary reduction without prior notice, these can serve as evidence.

**Action Steps:**
- File a complaint with the Maryland Department of Labor's Employment Standards Service.
- Consult with an employment attorney to assess the strength of your claim and potential remedies.

---

**Summary:**
- **Severance Promise:** While the verbal promise might not be legally binding due to the subsequent text message, highlighting the inconsistency could be a strategic move.
- **Salary Reduction:** The lack of advance written notice for your salary reduction appears to be a clear violation of Maryland law, providing a solid basis for a claim.

If you need assistance drafting communications or pursuing these matters further, feel free to ask.

parts: my biweekly income went from $5,000 to $3,333.34 on March 1.  As of today, assuming four pay periods, what is the amount of money lost?

Alright, let’s run the numbers, Mark:

---

### 📉 **Old Salary (Before March 1):**  
- $5,000 biweekly  
- = $10,000/month on average

### 📉 **New Salary (After March 1):**  
- $3,333.34 biweekly  
- = ~$6,666.68/month on average

---

### 🧾 **Pay Periods Since March 1**  
You mentioned 4 pay periods. That means:

- **Loss per paycheck:**  
  $5,000 – $3,333.34 = **$1,666.66**

- **Total lost over 4 pay periods:**  
  $1,666.66 × 4 = **$6,666.64**

---

### ✅ Final Answer:
**You've lost $6,666.64 in gross wages** since March 1 due to the unauthorized salary reduction.

Want me to prep language or a spreadsheet documenting this for a formal dispute or legal complaint?
so what would that be worth if i file a complain?

Now we’re talking real leverage. Here’s how it breaks down if you file a complaint under **Maryland’s Wage Payment and Collection Law** (which you absolutely qualify under, based on what you told me):

---

### 💥 Your Case:
- Employer **reduced your salary without written notice or consent**
- You **continued to work under the belief** you were earning $120,000/year ($5,000 biweekly)
- You lost **$6,666.64** so far in unpaid wages

---

### 🧑‍⚖️ What You Could Recover (If Successful):

#### 1. **Back Wages**
- The **base amount** you’re owed is:  
  ✅ **$6,666.64**

#### 2. **Treble Damages (Up to 3x Penalty)**
Under Maryland law, if the employer is found to have *withheld wages in bad faith*, the court may award up to **three times the withheld amount** (called “treble damages”).

- ✅ **$6,666.64 × 3 = $19,999.92** total potential recovery

#### 3. **Attorney’s Fees**
- If you win, your **legal fees are recoverable**, meaning you don’t have to pay out of pocket. Most lawyers who take these cases do so on contingency if the numbers are good (and yours are).

---

### 🚨 So: What’s It Worth?

| Component            | Amount         |
|---------------------|----------------|
| Back wages owed     | $6,666.64      |
| Treble damages      | $13,333.28     |
| **Total Potential** | **$19,999.92** |

(Plus legal fees covered)

---

### 🧭 Strategy

You can **use this as serious leverage** right now—whether or not you formally file.

Want me to draft a version of:  
> “I’m not looking to escalate, but I am aware that Maryland law may entitle me to up to 3x lost wages due to the unilateral reduction in pay. I’d prefer to resolve this cleanly if we can.”

Or do you want to prep for **formal filing** with the **Maryland Department of Labor** or a private employment attorney? I can guide you step-by-step.
let's think of this.  They just offered to pay me a lump sum of what the employment would be.  So basically 4 checks.  what would that be - and what would that be with taxes taken out?

Yup, let’s break that down clean and quick.

---

### 🧮 **They’re Offering 4 Paychecks as a Lump Sum**

Each paycheck (under the *reduced* salary) is:  
**$3,333.34**

So:

- **4 checks = 4 × $3,333.34 = $13,333.36 (gross)**

---

### 💸 **What You’d Take Home (Estimated After Taxes)**

Let’s assume:
- You’re in Maryland
- Filing single
- No major deductions
- Standard tax withholdings (Federal + State + FICA ≈ 30% total)

Estimated taxes:  
**30% × $13,333.36 = $4,000.01**

---

### ✅ **Net Payout (After Tax):**
**$13,333.36 – $4,000.01 ≈ $9,333.35**

---

### 💡 Bonus Insight:

If they **code it as severance**, it’ll likely get taxed like a bonus:
- That means **lump sum tax withholding** could be even higher (~37–40% depending on bracket + FICA still applies).
- Your net could shrink to around **$8,000 – $8,500** if treated as a bonus rather than regular W-2 income.

**Want to minimize tax hit?** You could ask:
> “Can this be processed as continuation of regular wages rather than a severance bonus? Just want to avoid inflated withholding.”

Want me to draft a clean ask or evaluate the number against your original 120K salary instead?
evaluate against the 120 please

Hell yeah, Mark—let’s compare the **real deal (what you *should’ve* gotten)** to what they’re now offering, based on your original $120K salary.

---

### 📈 **What You Were Supposed to Be Paid (at $120K/year)**

- $120,000 ÷ 26 pay periods = **$4,615.38 per paycheck**
- Over 4 pay periods:  
  **4 × $4,615.38 = $18,461.52 gross**

---

### 📉 **What They’re Offering Now (at $80K/year)**

- $80,000 ÷ 26 = **$3,076.92 per paycheck**
- Over 4 pay periods:  
  **4 × $3,076.92 = $12,307.68 gross**

⚠️ Note: You previously said $3,333.34, which reflects a slightly higher rate than $80K/year ($86,667/year). So let’s run *both* versions:

---

#### 📊 Scenario A: Based on $80K/year  
- **Loss over 4 checks = $18,461.52 – $12,307.68 = $6,153.84**

#### 📊 Scenario B: Based on $3,333.34 biweekly  
- $3,333.34 × 4 = **$13,333.36**
- **Loss = $18,461.52 – $13,333.36 = $5,128.16**

---

### 🧾 **Net Take-Home Comparison (Estimated After Taxes)**

#### ✅ What You Should’ve Taken Home (30% tax rate)  
- $18,461.52 – 30% ≈ **$12,923.06**

#### ❌ What They’re Offering Now  
- $13,333.36 – 30% ≈ **$9,333.35**

---

### ⚠️ **True Cost to You = ~$3,590 in lost take-home pay**

---

### 🧠 TL;DR

| Scenario                 | Gross Pay | Est. Net Pay | Difference from $120K |
|--------------------------|-----------|--------------|------------------------|
| What you *should’ve* earned | $18,461.52 | $12,923.06   | –                      |
| What they’re offering     | $13,333.36 | $9,333.35    | **–$3,590**            |

So if they think you’re going to walk away happy from this on the $80K math? **They're shorting you** around **$3.5K in real money**—and that's **not even counting** your legal leverage over the unauthorized pay cut.

Want me to build a side-by-side table or drop a one-liner back in that next convo to show you’re not fooled by the math?

parts:
Absolutely, Mark. Filing a wage claim in Maryland is a straightforward process, and here's how you can go about it:

---

### 📝 How to File a Wage Claim in Maryland

1. **Download and Complete the Wage Claim Form**:
   - Access the form from the Maryland Department of Labor's website: [Wage Claim Form Instructions - Employment Standards Service (ESS)](https://labor.maryland.gov/labor/wages/essclaimform.shtml).
   - Fill in your personal and employer information, employment dates, pay rate, and the amount you believe you're owed.

2. **Submit the Form**:
   - Email the completed form to: [DLDLIMdLaborComplaint-dllr@Maryland.gov](mailto:DLDLIMdLaborComplaint-dllr@Maryland.gov)
   - Or mail it to:
     > Maryland Department of Labor  
     > Division of Labor and Industry  
     > Employment Standards Service  
     > 10946 Golden West Dr., Suite 160  
     > Hunt Valley, MD 21031

3. **Await Response**:
   - The Department will review your claim and may contact you for additional information.
   - They will also reach out to your employer as part of the investigation process.

---

### ⏳ Timeline

- **Investigation Duration**: The process can take several weeks to a few months, depending on the complexity of the case and the Department's workload.

---

### 💡 Additional Considerations

- **Statute of Limitations**: You have up to three years from the date the wages were due to file a claim.
- **Retaliation**: It's illegal for employers to retaliate against employees for filing a wage claim. If you experience retaliation, you can file a separate complaint.

---

If you need assistance filling out the form or gathering the necessary documentation, feel free to ask.

nice - not yet.  I have 120 hours of unused PTO.  Do they owe me that as well, or not in MD?

Ooooh. **Nice catch, Mark.** Let’s talk about **PTO payout law in Maryland**—because yeah, they *might* owe you, depending on what’s in their written policies.

---

### 🧾 Maryland Law on PTO Payouts (the real deal)

Under **Maryland law**, employers **are not required by statute to pay out unused vacation or PTO** **unless**:

> 1. **The company’s written policy or employee handbook says they will**,  
> **or**  
> 2. **There is no clear written forfeiture policy.**

So, if they’ve *ever* said something like “we pay out unused PTO when employees leave” in your offer letter, handbook, or even an email—you have a solid claim.

---

### 🎯 What That Means for You

- If **Lumina’s policy is silent or vague**, they owe you the **full 120 hours of PTO**.
- If their policy says something like **“PTO is forfeited upon resignation”**, they may be off the hook—but only **if** they gave you that policy **in writing ahead of time**.
- **If they told you you’d get paid out**, even verbally, and didn’t update that policy in writing? You might have a claim anyway.

---

### 💰 What’s 120 Hours Worth?

If your *reduced* hourly rate is based on $80K/year:
- $80,000 ÷ 2,080 hours/year = **$38.46/hour**
- 120 hours × $38.46 = **$4,615.20**

If we go by your *original* $120K rate:
- $120,000 ÷ 2,080 = **$57.69/hour**
- 120 hours × $57.69 = **$6,922.80**

So depending on how you price your worth, we’re looking at **$4.6K to nearly $7K**.

---

### 💼 What to Do Next

- Ask HR: **“Does company policy allow for PTO payout upon voluntary resignation?”**
- If they say no: **Ask for the written policy in effect during your employment.**
- If they fumble or don’t provide anything clear? You’ve got grounds to **either negotiate** or **file later**.

---

Want me to help you draft a sneaky-nice email that casually locks them into their answer without tipping your hand? Like:

> “Just confirming—does company policy include payout of unused PTO upon separation? I believe I have ~120 hours accrued. Just want to align expectations for final compensation.”

💥 Let’s go if you want it.

parts:
Absolutely, Mark. The law you're referring to is **Maryland Labor and Employment Article § 3-507.2**, which is part of the **Maryland Wage Payment and Collection Law (MWPCL)**. Here's a breakdown:

---

### 📜 **Maryland Labor & Employment § 3-507.2 – Action to Recover Unpaid Wages**

**(a)** If an employer fails to pay an employee in accordance with § 3-502 (regular pay) or § 3-505 (final wages upon termination), and two weeks have passed since the wages were due, the employee may bring an action against the employer to recover the unpaid wages.

**(b)** If a court finds that the employer withheld wages in violation of this subtitle and not due to a bona fide dispute, the court may award the employee up to three times the amount of the unpaid wages, along with reasonable attorney's fees and other costs.

---

### 🔍 **Key Points:**

- **Two-week waiting period**: You must wait two weeks after the wages were due before initiating legal action.

- **Treble damages**: If the court determines there was no legitimate dispute over the wages, it can award up to three times the amount owed.

- **Attorney's fees**: The employer may also be required to pay your legal costs.

---

### 📚 **Further Reading:**

- You can read the full text of § 3-507.2 here: [Justia – Maryland Labor and Employment Code § 3-507.2](https://law.justia.com/codes/maryland/labor-and-employment/title-3/subtitle-5/section-3-507-2/)

- For a comprehensive overview of the Maryland Wage Payment and Collection Law, including § 3-507.2, refer to this PDF: [Maryland Wage Payment and Collection Law – Full Text](https://dcwagelaw.com/wp-content/uploads/maryland-wage-payment-collection-law-mwpcl-full-text.pdf)

---

If you need assistance drafting a demand letter or have questions about the process, feel free to ask.

parts:
Absolutely, Mark. The specific Maryland law addressing your situation is **Maryland Labor and Employment Code § 3-504**, which mandates that employers provide employees with **at least one pay period's advance notice** before any change in wage rates.

---

### 📜 **Maryland Labor and Employment Code § 3-504 – Notice of Wages and Paydays**

Under this statute:

- **Advance Notice Requirement**: Employers must notify employees of any change in their wage rate **at least one pay period in advance**.

- **Method of Notification**: The notice must be provided in writing, ensuring that employees are fully informed of any impending changes to their compensation.

Failure to adhere to this requirement can result in legal consequences for the employer.

---

### ⚖️ **Implications for Your Case**

Given that your salary was reduced from $120,000 to $80,000 without your consent or prior written notice, this action appears to be in violation of § 3-504. Such a unilateral pay cut without proper notice is considered a breach of Maryland's wage payment laws.

---

### 🛠 **Potential Remedies**

If you choose to pursue this matter, Maryland law provides for the following remedies:

- **Recovery of Unpaid Wages**: You may be entitled to recover the difference in wages resulting from the unauthorized pay reduction.

- **Treble Damages**: In cases where the employer's violation is found to be willful and not due to a bona fide dispute, courts may award up to **three times the amount of unpaid wages**.

- **Attorney's Fees and Costs**: The law also allows for the recovery of reasonable attorney's fees and other associated legal costs.

---

For a comprehensive understanding, you can review the full text of § 3-504 here: [Justia – Maryland Labor and Employment Code § 3-504](https://law.justia.com/codes/maryland/labor-and-employment/title-3/subtitle-5/section-3-504/).

If you need assistance drafting a formal complaint or exploring legal avenues, feel free to reach out.

That’s the heart of it, Mark—and you’re asking the exact right question: **“What actually counts as consent under Maryland law when your wages get cut?”**

Let’s break it down like a badass employment lawyer who just finished their espresso and is out for blood.

---

### 🧾 Under Maryland Law:

#### 📜 **Section 3-504** says:
> Employers **must provide written notice of a wage change** at least one pay period in advance.

But it **doesn’t say** that you have to sign something to accept it. So here's the real-world answer:

---

### ⚖️ **What Constitutes “Consent”?**

#### 1. **Documented Consent (Strongest for Employer)**
- You sign something (email, form, acknowledgment)—that’s airtight for them.

#### 2. **Implied Consent (Gray Zone, Often Disputed)**
- You *keep working* and *accept paychecks* at the reduced rate, without protesting in writing.
- Courts sometimes interpret that as **tacit acceptance**, even if you never explicitly agreed.

#### 3. **Lack of Written Notice (Your Power Move)**
- If they **never gave you written notice before reducing your pay**, even if you “accepted” the new checks, **they still broke the law**.

> ⛏️ You can argue: *“I didn’t consent—I had no idea what was happening, and I had no choice but to keep working until I could leave. That doesn’t make it legal.”*

---

### 🧠 Real Talk:

- **Did they ever give you anything in writing** saying “your pay is now $80K effective March 1” *before* it happened?
  - No? That’s a violation—**even if you didn’t complain immediately.**
- If they **told you verbally** and you kept working, it’s murky. But **verbal notice isn’t enough under Maryland law.**

---

### 🎯 Strategic Summary:

- You didn’t truly “consent.” You **complied** because you were stuck.
- **Consent requires informed choice**—and a *unilateral* cut with no written notice isn’t a choice, it’s a corner.
- You have the **right to challenge it retroactively** under §3-504, and potentially recover up to **3x the amount lost** if they’re found to have acted in bad faith.

---

Want me to help you write a “just documenting for my records” entry in case you ever want to file? Or build a folder that locks all of this down in your favor?

You’re not trapped anymore. You’re tracking. And they might not even know you’re loaded.

I was **never presented with a written notice or acknowledgment form** regarding this salary change. No email, memo, or formal policy was shared with me in advance of the adjustment, and I did not sign any documentation agreeing to the new rate.

---

#### 🔹 Legal Reference:
Per **Maryland Labor and Employment Code § 3-504**, employers must provide **written notice of wage changes at least one pay period in advance**. This requirement was not met in my case.

This may constitute a violation of Maryland’s **Wage Payment and Collection Law**, and could entitle me to recovery of:
- The difference in wages over affected pay periods
- Up to **3x damages** under **§ 3-507.2** if bad faith is determined
- Reasonable attorney’s fees and legal costs

---

#### 🔹 Total Loss (as of April 21, 2025):
- **Gross wages lost:** $6,666.64 over 4 pay periods
- **Potential recovery (3x):** $19,999.92 + attorney’s fees

---

#### 🔹 Notes:
This memo is created solely to document facts while still preserving goodwill. I have not yet filed a claim but reserve the right to do so within Maryland’s statute of limitations (3 years from date of first missed payment).

---
